Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Role of Glacial History on the Structure and Functioning of Ecological Communities in the Shackleton Glacier Region of the Transantarctic Mountains
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will characterize the functional, taxonomic, biotic and abiotic drivers of soil ecosystems in the Trans Antarctic Mountains (one of the most remote and harsh terrestrial landscapes on the planet). The work will utilize new high-throughput DNA and RNA sequencing technologies to identify members of the microbial communities and determine if the microbial community structures are independent of local environmental heterogeneities. In addition the project will determine if microbial diversity and function are correlated with time since the last glacial maximum (LGM). The expected results will greatly contribute to our knowledge regarding rates of microbial succession and help define the some of the limits to life and life-maintaining processes on Earth.

The project will analyze genomes and RNA derived from these genomes to describe the relationships between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning from soils above and below LGM elevations and to correlate these with the environmental drivers associated with their development during the last ~18,000 years. The team will identify the taxonomic diversity and the functional genetic composition within a broad suite of soil biota and examine their patterns of assembly and distribution within the framework of their geological legacies. The project will mentor participants from undergraduate students to postdoctoral researchers and prepare them to effectively engage in research to meet their career aspirations. The project will contribute to ongoing public education efforts through relationships with K-12 teachers and administrators- to include University-Public School partnerships. Less formal activities include public lecture series and weblogs aimed at providing information on Antarctic polar desert ecosystems to the general public. Targeted classrooms near each PI's institution will participate in online, real-time discussions about current topics in Antarctic ecosystems research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ice-free areas within the Transantarctic Mountains in Antarctica are believed to contain some of the oldest exposed soil environments on Earth and have been greatly modified by the advance and retreat of glaciers throughout the recent geologic past. These polar desert environments have low levels of light during the winter, low temperatures, low organic carbon, low availability of liquid water, and high salt concentrations. However, despite generally biologically unfavorable conditions, soil organisms persist. During the last ice age, ~20,000 years ago, the East and West Antarctic Ice Sheets (EAIS and WAIS) were larger and thicker than present and covered much of the currently exposed soil environments. Genetic studies of Antarctic soil organisms show evolutionary changes that happened long ago, indicating these organisms found favorable environments in which to live while glacier were highest during the last ice-age.

During the 2017-2018 austral summer, 220 soil samples were collected from these ice-free regions for chemical analysis along the Shackleton Glacier, a major outlet glacier of the EAIS located in the Queen Maud Mountains. Before this work, there were few chemical data from the Central Transantarctic Mountains, which are among the least human-modified environments on Earth. We found that the salts in these soils were dominated by sulfates and nitrates, and that the abundance of these salts varied with elevation, distance from the coast, and exposure age. The stable isotopic composition "fingerprints" of these salts indicated that they primarily came from the atmosphere.

Nitrate salts dissolve very quickly in water and accumulate in soils only under persistent dry conditions and prolonged exposure to the atmosphere, because water would quickly wash them away. The amount of these salts and other elements from the atmosphere were used to estimate the age of the soil. These data showed that the youngest soils we sampled were near the end of the Shackleton Glacier and along the sides of the glacier. Additionally, the highest elevation and furthest inland samples have remained hyper-arid since at least the Pleistocene (>12,000 years ago).

The younger soils had nutrients most favorable for biological growth as well as the lowest total salt concentrations, and lowest chlorate and perchlorate concentrations (chemical compounds that can be toxic to biology). Soils that had not been been covered by glaciers recently had accumulated high concentrations of salts, which rendered them as unsuitable habitats for soil organisms to survive over long periods of time.

Lastly, we used statistics and machine learning algorithms to predict the chemistry of soils in areas where samples were not collected based on geography, glacial history, and the present and past availability of liquid water. Because samples are so hard to collect in Antarctica, this model can be used in the future to predict soil chemistry becased one parameters we can measure with maps and satellites.

These findings are vital to understanding 1) the source of salts controlling and understanding how soil organisms live in deserts, 2) how ecosystems change following large-scale changes in climate, such as advance and retreat of glaciers and 3) how nutrients cycle and landscapes develop in extreme environments, including on other planets and moons in our solar system.
